title: Wednesday, 25th July, 2018
bodyHTML:
11:07 am
BE11:07am

Well, that was tricky.

BornCynic Morning
nightingale20201 morning all
DRichi Good morning!
BE11:08am

Welcome to Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily thing with etc. Small system bork this morning, mostly my fault.

Blank canvas good morning everyone
AAAA salut la compagnie !
BE11:09am

So ...... here's interesting.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

GSK and 23andMe sign agreement to leverage genetic insights for the development of novel medicines

Multi-year collaboration expected to identify novel drug targets, tackle new subsets of disease and enable rapid progression of clinical programmes

SupposeToBeWorking... Morning all
BE11:09am

This is ........ surprising!

BE11:09am

GSK and 23andMe today unveiled an exclusive four-year collaboration that will focus on research and development of innovative new medicines and potential cures, using human genetics as the basis for discovery. The collaboration will combine 23andMe's large-scale genetic resources and advanced data science skills, with the scientific and medical knowledge and commercialisation expertise of GSK. The goal of the collaboration is to gather insights and discover novel drug targets driving disease progression and develop therapies for serious unmet medical needs based on those discoveries.

With over 5 million customers, 23andMe offers those with an interest in genetics the opportunity to learn more about their personal genetic profile. 23andMe customers can also choose to participate in research and contribute their information to a unique and dynamic database, which is now the world's largest genetic and phenotypic resource.

Excel Developer Hello sun seekers

BE11:10am

For those unfamiliar, 23andMe sells this kind of thing

BE11:10am

anonymous254 if the goal (presumably) of "identifying novel targets" is to create a drug, struggling to see how this relationship would work in practice to achieve the outcome given how drugs are created and relationships internally between drug development teams in pharma. Perhaps more value lies in the "rapid progression of clinical programmes" if they can help on clinical trials design? but these feels theoretical also. Overall feels like PR.

Investors will have little to change the concern over Sublocade launch, with only $2m in sales since launch, despite peak sales guidance of greater than $1bn (Citi $800m) being reiterated. We expect further transparency on the launch difficulties in this morning’s presentation. US sales of Suboxone film imply double digit realized price erosion, as tactical rebating continues and the mix of Medicaid channel increases, leading to a 2% miss vs consensus.

A. M. Scrolling in the mobile app is a hit and (mostly) miss affair.

Suboxone film revenues for 3Q18 will be significantly impacted by stock of Dr Reddy’s generic film which flooded the market prior to the implication of a temporary restraining order (TRO). According to IMS data generic film will have at least 4% volume share in Jul if the current rate of prescriptions continues.

PandaMan Scrolling works fine for me in Chrome

$2m Sublocade sales is, let's be clear, bloody awful.

chopper bear morning from my sickbed - whooping cough apparently :-(
11:26 am
BE11:26am

But we knew about the problems with payers and the reluctance among doctors to prescribe the stuff.

TB Marchionne :( ... deserved pic of the day
BE11:28am

I'm not clear why $4m sales would've been very much better than $2m sales given they're both very very small numbers caused by problems that might or might not be overcome in time.

BE11:28am

So why are they down 15%? Dunno. Here's Stifel.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

While previously flagged initial frictions with the new reimbursement and distribution model for Sublocade have contributed to slow uptake, $2m of sales is lower than buy-side expectations, in our view. In particular, the prescription journey (time taken from prescription initiation to injection) has been slow although INDV has lowered it from 43-62 days at launch to 27-36 days currently. Additionally, payer coverage increased to 67% of lives covered, which is positive, but we look to the 11:30am UK call on how INDV plans to accelerate Sublocade uptake in 2H given its $25-50m guidance.

Tom Dalgleish Maybe Ferrari would get a class action if they knew of Marchionne's health before
BE11:28am

There is a high awareness among buprenorphine-prescribing physicians (79%). 1,300 physicians have initiated prescription journeys and only 384 have actually injected Sublocade which highlights the initial inertia getting Sublocade access to meet demand. That said, only 30 physicians are treating fewer than 5 patients so there is clearly slow adoption at this stage.

BE11:29am

Fewer than five patients.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

Oh, and if you're playing volatility ......

BE11:29am

INDV has changed its tone on its litigation update with regards to discussions with the DoJ and now states it is in advanced discussions about a possible resolution to its investigations. We had previously expected that the increase and restructuring of the provision at FY17 results in Feb, might signal progression towards settlement. We view any settlement as a major positive catalyst.

BE11:30am

Sorry, correction, above is Jefferies not Stifel.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Though they're both buyers.

BE11:31am

We continue to believe these issues are being resolved and with private insurance coverage now at 67% and a Medicaid Q code in place from 1 July, prescription filing should rapidly improve. Reiterate Buy.

BE11:31am

That was Stifel not Jefferies.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

Turning back to the headline, though, here's the upshot via SocGen.

BE11:38am

At first glance, it looks as if there are few if any surprises in Vodafone’s 1Q results, with management reiterating FY guidance. The company reported €9,850m group service revenues, 0.6% below consensus on €9,914m. No details are given for EBITDA, FCF or net debt. However, ‘scratching the surface’ we find a tangible deterioration in yoy growth trends with more to come.

BE11:39am

(Why do analysts always put idioms in quotes? We know you're not literally scratching the surface.)

11:39 am
BE11:40am

VOD’s group service revenue grew yoy by 0.3% (ex forex), a 120bp reduction from last quarter (when yoy growth came in at +1.5%). The main driver was a significant deterioration in Italy, which recorded a yoy revenue fall of 6.5% vs +0.7% growth last quarter. Importantly, Spain and the UK also recorded a tangible deterioration in growth trends (from +1.0% to -2.2% for Spain and from -3.4% to -4.9% for the UK).

BE11:40am

You'll remember Iliad's launch in Italy was extremely successful.

BE11:41am

€5.99-a-month deal. Signed up a million folk in a month and a half.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

https://www.ft.com...-bf9e-8771d5404543

#REF! @BE I'd imagine over eager editors/reviewers/compliance rather than the analyst...
BE11:42am

In terms of the number fudge ......

#REF! Similar to why you sometimes see OTT sub-clauses 'in our opinion'
BE11:42am

VOD’s organic growth is supported by inflation in EM markets. In 1Q VOD reported +14.0% yoy “organic” growth in Turkey, which helped to mitigate the rising pressure in European revenues. However, in euro terms Turkey recorded a -14.1% yoy fall in revenues, as a high level of inflation (which helps revenues denominated in local currency) leads to currency depreciation. This (partly) explains why VOD’s yoy statutory growth in service revenues came in a -4.2% vs the +0.3% recorded by VOD in organic service revenue.

Soundbuy ITV - no real surprises looking at this morning's action......
nightingale20201 I though VOD's India # is bad...
11:43 am

So ...... overall, we get figures coming back a bit on FX and plenty to be bearish about if you're already bearish.

BE11:44am

If you want a valuation argument, here's JP Morgan's.

BE11:44am

Mar-19E organic financials are unch. But FX lowers revenues and EBITDA by ~1%. Longer-term, FX twinned with small cuts across Italy/Spain lower revenues, EBITDA and EFCF by 2%, 2% and 3% pa respectively. Mar-19E SoTP-based TP 270p (prev 280p). Mar-19E EV/EBITDA 6.7x, EFCF yield 8.2% and dividend yield 7.5%.

Mostly on BT's reluctance to bundle free mobile data with broadband.

Excel Developer @bluesky21: weren't there stories about cheaper super fast broadband, bad for margins for all
Bluesky21 I think mobile is one of the only 2 businesses at BT that are doing well
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Just had great service from BT: Phone out for 1 week, broadband out for 3. No letter of apology and had to chase them for a £20 credit to the account. Great eh?
BE11:49am

Here's the gist of it.

BE11:49am

Having done the "hard yards", and with a 7% dividend, one could expect some easing of the environment and a potential relief rally (esp. if defensive stocks come back into vogue). However we are hard pressed to find any catalysts that could cause the market to reassess BT's prospects in the next 12 months. (1) CEO: The lack of CEO leads to an ongoing interregnum period, (2) Convergence: BT's approach appears to be 'safety first'. We continue to believe that BT's strategic position could allow it to use convergence (and esp. mobile data) to stop line loss and neutralise the threat from AltNets (see Thucydides Trap , 13 April). However BT's incremental approach is likely to take several years before it becomes 'mass market'. (3) Regulation: As BT revealed at its FY18 results, the next three years are likely to see £1bn headwind coming from regulation, up from the £500m seen over the past few years. This impact is magnified by the multiplier effect of lowered input prices for competitors allowing them to lower their retail prices to compete with BT.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

.... "hard yards". We can tell it's an idiom because it's in quotes. Otherwise we might get confused and think Jan du Plessis had, I dunno, run a marathon or something.

BE11:51am

There's also a bit of grumbling about BT's new policy of not announcing net adds for mobile or broadband.

BE11:51am

While we understand the desire to move away from 'net adds' as the market matures, not disclosing such important metrics may cause concern, given the widely held sceptical view that companies tend to obfuscate bad news. Indeed, reduced disclosure often, in our view, portends badly for future operational performance.

11:51 am

Bluesky21 I think US cable operators disclose broadband net adds, and even break them out into data, voice, video, etc.
BornCynic "Thucydides Trap" ? In an analysts report ?

Bananalyst late to the 23and me stuff. I looked into it for fun, but changed my mind as they do indeed say they will use your data and it's backed by google (started by Sergey Brin's wife). It is quite obvious a dna data collection business that would one day sell its database. FDA banned it in the US so they started collecting UK dna. All kinds of shady.
BE11:54am

(@Fox: re Vod's dividend, when you have equity free cashflow of £3bn on and net debt of £33bn is it really that useful to talk about equity free cashflow?)

BE11:55am

Fosun International Ltd., the Chinese group backed by billionaire Guo Guangchang, is considering an offer for all or parts of Belgian insurer Ageas in what could be its boldest move to expand its international footprint, people familiar with the matter said.

BE11:58am

Takeover speculation gives BTG a shot in the arm One of Britain's most prominent healthcare companies shot to the top of the FTSE 250 amid speculation that it was being considered a takeover target. BTG closed up 6.7 per cent, or 33¼p, at 529½p as rumours spread of preparations for a bid.

Quick line from Exane.

BE12:06pm

SAN’s FL B3 CET1 declined 20bp q/q to 10.8% (the company is leveraged 22x). More importantly its TE per share declined 0.4% q/q according to our calculations, in spite of the reported profits. Over the past three years, the company’s TE per share has declined 2%, according to our estimates, in spite of EUR18bn in cumulative profits being reported over the same period of time.

BE12:07pm

22x!

Flaneur Sorry that last coment was @Alewis2005
12:06 pm
BE12:07pm

They're underperform down to 5eur.

BE12:07pm

SAN shares are currently trading, according to our estimates, at 9x 2019e P/E and at 1x 2019e
P/TE for an expected 12% 2019e ROTE. If we were to add all the dividends paid (both cash and
scrip) to the NAV per share of the company, we estimate SAN owners have had a 6% CAGR
return over the past four years – approximately half of what we consider to be the required cost of
capital for the existing business model. Going forward we expect the company to deliver returns
closer to the cost of capital, but a successful long-term investment in the company shares requires,
in our opinion, a much lower entry point given the potential dilution risk posed by the business
model (two material capital increases over the past four years).
